name: Amla
habitat: Moist tropical and subtropical deciduous forests, riverbanks, orchard margins and hedgerows in warm climates
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and widely naturalized across South and Southeast Asia through cultivation
description: Amla is a medium-sized deciduous tree prized for its small, tart fruits extremely rich in vitamin C and antioxidants; widely used in Ayurvedic medicine for digestion, hair care, immunity support, and traditional tonic preparations across centuries.

name: Curry Plant
habitat: Dry, well-drained rocky soils, coastal scrublands, and sun-exposed Mediterranean slopes with sparse vegetation
origin: Native to the Mediterranean Basin, particularly coastal southern Europe and nearby island regions
description: A low-growing aromatic shrub valued for its silvery foliage and essential oils; often cultivated for fragrance, ornamental borders, and traditional remedies rather than as a culinary curry ingredient, with insect-repelling properties.

name: Betel Leaf
habitat: Humid tropical lowlands, shaded forest understories, and cultivated trellises near water sources in warm climates
origin: Native to Southeast Asia where it is widely cultivated and integrated into cultural practices across the region
description: A vigorous tropical climber with glossy heart-shaped leaves traditionally used in many Asian cultures for ceremonial chewing, medicinal preparations, and as a wrapper for betel quid; leaves have mild aromatic and therapeutic properties.

name: Bamboo
habitat: Moist subtropical and tropical forests, riverine corridors, secondary growth woodlands and managed plantations
origin: Native primarily to Asia with many species naturalized or cultivated across tropical and temperate regions worldwide
description: Rapidly growing woody grasses forming dense stands used for construction materials, furniture, paper, erosion control, and food; ecologically important for soil stabilization and as habitat for many wildlife species.

name: Spinach
habitat: Temperate cultivated fields, garden beds, irrigated vegetable plots and seasonally sown croplands
origin: Originally from the Persian region (modern Iran), later introduced and cultivated across Europe and Asia
description: A fast-growing leafy green vegetable valued for its high vitamin and mineral content, especially iron and folate; commonly used in salads, cooked dishes, and traditional cuisines worldwide.

name: Coriander
habitat: Open cultivated fields, kitchen gardens, and marginal agricultural plots with well-drained soils and full sun
origin: Originating from southern Europe and Western Asia, now widely cultivated and naturalized globally
description: An annual herb grown for both its leafy greens (cilantro) and seeds (coriander) with a distinctive citrusy aroma; widely used in cuisines across Asia, Europe, and the Americas and valued in traditional medicine.

name: Ashoka
habitat: Moist tropical and semi-evergreen forests, riverine tracts and well-watered garden settings in warm climates
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent where it is historically revered and commonly planted in temple gardens
description: A medium-sized ornamental and sacred tree prized for its dense clusters of fragrant, showy orange-red flowers and traditional medicinal uses in Ayurveda, particularly for gynecological and reproductive health preparations.

name: Noni
habitat: Coastal and inland tropical lowland forests, disturbed clearings, riverbanks, and cultivated garden plots in warm humid climates
origin: Native to Southeast Asia and Australasia, later spread across the Pacific Islands and into tropical regions worldwide through cultivation
description: Noni is a small evergreen tree producing large, pungent fruits widely used in traditional medicine; fruit, leaves and juice are applied for digestive support, pain relief, and immune remedies, and it is cultivated broadly in tropical smallholdings and home gardens.

name: Custard Apple
habitat: Dry tropical lowlands, well-drained open woodlands, home gardens and smallholder orchards in warm regions
origin: Believed to be native to Central America and the Caribbean, later spread and cultivated in tropical regions worldwide
description: A small to medium-sized fruit tree producing sweet, pulpy fruits with segmented flesh; fruits are eaten fresh or used in desserts, and the species is commonly grown in home gardens for local consumption.

name: Lemongrass
habitat: Sunny, well-drained fields, garden beds, and roadside plantings in tropical and subtropical climates
origin: Native to Southeast Asia where it is widely cultivated and naturalized across tropical regions
description: A tall, aromatic grass with fragrant lemon-scented leaves used extensively in cooking, herbal teas, and traditional medicine; valued for its essential oils, digestive benefits, and insect-repellent properties.

name: Papaya
habitat: Tropical lowlands, disturbed areas, garden plots and plantations with fertile, well-drained soils and ample sunlight
origin: Native to Central America and southern Mexico and now widely cultivated throughout the tropics
description: A fast-growing fruit tree known for its large, nutrient-rich fruits containing digestive enzymes (papain); widely grown for fresh consumption, culinary uses, and traditional medicine across tropical countries.

name: Curry Leaf
habitat: Tropical and subtropical home gardens, hedgerows and cultivated groves with partial shade and regular watering
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and Sri Lanka, extensively cultivated across South and Southeast Asia
description: A small aromatic tree whose glossy pinnate leaves are essential in South Asian cooking for flavoring curries, chutneys and tempering oils; also used in traditional medicine for digestive and hair-care remedies.

name: Lemon
habitat: Subtropical orchards, home gardens, and well-drained terraces with full sun exposure and frost protection
origin: Believed to have originated in South Asia and Southeast Asia and later spread through trade to the Mediterranean and beyond
description: A small evergreen tree producing acidic citrus fruits rich in vitamin C; widely cultivated for culinary, preservative, medicinal and cleaning uses with many cultivated varieties and hybrids.

name: Indian Laurel
habitat: Disturbed roadsides, wastelands, riverbanks and dry deciduous forests where it tolerates poor soils and intermittent moisture
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and parts of Southeast Asia where it grows commonly in wild and cultivated settings
description: A hardy multi-stemmed shrub or small tree with aromatic leaves used in traditional remedies for respiratory and inflammatory conditions; commonly planted as a medicinal and shade-providing species.

name: Henna
habitat: Arid and semi-arid plains, cultivated gardens and dry scrublands with well-drained soils and ample sunlight
origin: Native to North Africa and parts of South Asia and widely cultivated in arid zones for dye production
description: A small shrub valued for its leaves which produce a natural reddish-brown dye used for body art, textiles and hair treatment; also used in traditional medicine and cultural ceremonies.

name: Mango
habitat: Tropical and subtropical orchards, mixed agroforestry systems, and well-drained plains with seasonal rainfall
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent with long history of domestication and spread across tropical regions worldwide
description: A large evergreen fruit tree producing sweet, fleshy fruits of high cultural and economic importance; cultivated in home gardens and commercial orchards for fresh consumption, processing and export.

name: Doddapatre
habitat: Shaded tropical gardens, moist understories, and pots near homes where soil is fertile and moisture retained
origin: Believed to originate from Africa and naturalized across tropical Asia where it is often cultivated in home gardens
description: A fragrant, fleshy-leaved herb used in traditional medicine and cooking; leaves are applied for respiratory and digestive complaints and commonly used as a culinary herb in local cuisines.

name: Giloy
habitat: Moist tropical forests, cultivated home gardens, and forest edges where it climbs host trees and shrubs
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and widely used and cultivated in traditional Ayurvedic systems across South Asia
description: A woody climbing shrub renowned in Ayurveda for immune-modulating properties; stems and extracts are used in traditional formulations for fever management, rejuvenation and general wellness.

name: Betel
habitat: Humid tropical lowlands, plantations, and garden plots often grown alongside coconut and other palms
origin: Native to Southeast Asia and cultivated extensively across the tropics for its stimulant seeds
description: A tall palm grown for its seeds (areca nuts) that are commonly chewed as part of betel quid in many Asian cultures; used socially and culturally with notable traditional significance.

name: Tulsi
habitat: Cultivated home gardens, courtyards and temple grounds in warm climates with regular watering
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and extensively cultivated across South Asia for religious and medicinal uses
description: A sacred basil species revered in Hindu tradition, valued for its aromatic leaves and use in traditional remedies for respiratory, digestive and stress-related conditions; commonly grown indoors and outdoors.

name: Pomegranate
habitat: Semi-arid and Mediterranean-type climates, terraced orchards, and home gardens tolerant of drought and poor soils
origin: Native to a region from modern-day Iran to northern India and widely cultivated across the Mediterranean and Asia
description: A deciduous shrub or small tree producing edible, antioxidant-rich seeds enclosed in a leathery fruit; valued for culinary uses, traditional remedies and ornamental planting in dry climates.

name: Castor
habitat: Disturbed tropical fields, roadside margins, and subtropical gardens where it tolerates varied soils and moisture regimes
origin: Believed to be native to eastern Africa and widely naturalized and cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide
description: A fast-growing perennial shrub cultivated for castor oil extracted from seeds used in industry and traditional medicine; seeds contain toxic ricin and must be processed carefully.

name: Jackfruit
habitat: Humid tropical lowlands, mixed orchards, and home gardens with rich, well-drained soils and consistent rainfall
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia where it has been cultivated for millennia
description: A large evergreen tree producing enormous starchy fruits eaten ripe or unripe; fruits and seeds are important local food sources and the tree is valued for timber and shade.

name: Insulin Plant
habitat: Tropical and subtropical garden beds, well-drained soils and partial shade with regular watering
origin: Native to Central America and cultivated in tropical gardens for reputed medicinal uses
description: A decorative medicinal plant traditionally used in folk medicine to help regulate blood sugar; leaves are consumed or applied in traditional remedies although clinical evidence varies.

name: Pepper
habitat: Humid tropical lowlands, shaded plantations, and trellised gardens with rich organic soils and consistent moisture
origin: Native to the Malabar coast of India and historically traded across Asia and the Mediterranean
description: A climbing vine cultivated for its dried berries (peppercorns) used globally as a spice; an economically important crop with numerous cultivars and culinary applications.

name: Raktachandini
habitat: Dry deciduous forests and rocky hillsides where drought-resistant trees persist with sparse canopies
origin: Endemic to parts of southern India where it has been historically valued for its distinct red heartwood
description: A slow-growing hardwood tree prized for its deep red timber used in traditional crafts and valued for medicinal and dye properties; often subject to conservation concerns due to overexploitation.

name: Aloe Vera
habitat: Arid and semi-arid zones, rocky slopes, and cultivated pots or beds with sandy, well-drained soils
origin: Believed native to the Arabian Peninsula and northeastern Africa, now widely cultivated in warm regions worldwide
description: A succulent plant widely grown for its soothing gel used in skin-care, wound treatment and cosmetic formulations; easy to cultivate and commonly kept as a medicinal houseplant.

name: Jasmine
habitat: Warm tropical gardens, courtyards and hedges with ample sunlight and regular moisture
origin: Native to South and Southeast Asia where it is cultivated for fragrant flowers
description: A fragrant flowering shrub cultivated for highly scented white blossoms used in perfumes, garlands and tea; valued culturally and ornamentally with many fragrant varieties.

name: Neem
habitat: Dry to semi-arid tropical and subtropical regions, roadside plantings and agroforestry systems tolerant of poor soils
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and widely planted across Africa, Asia and other tropical regions
description: A fast-growing tree widely used for its broad medicinal properties, natural insecticidal compounds, and traditional remedies; leaves, bark and oil are used in diverse applications from healthcare to agriculture.

name: Geranium
habitat: Cultivated garden beds, containers and temperate beds with good drainage and full to partial sun
origin: Native to South Africa and widely cultivated worldwide for ornamental and essential oil production
description: An aromatic flowering plant grown for its scented foliage and essential oils used in perfumery, aromatherapy and ornamental gardening; several cultivars exist with varied scents and colors.

name: Rose
habitat: Cultivated gardens, hedgerows, and managed orchard borders in temperate and subtropical climates
origin: Believed to have originated in parts of Asia with cultivation spreading globally over millennia
description: A globally cultivated woody shrub prized for its showy fragrant flowers used ornamentally, in perfumery, and for symbolic cultural purposes; numerous cultivated varieties exist for diverse climates.

name: Guava
habitat: Tropical and subtropical home gardens, orchards and secondary forests tolerant of a variety of soils
origin: Native to Central America and widely cultivated throughout the tropics for its edible fruits
description: A small to medium fruit tree producing vitamin C-rich fruits eaten fresh or processed; valued for its adaptability, quick fruiting and use in jams, juices and traditional diets.

name: Hibiscus
habitat: Tropical and subtropical gardens, hedges and containers with full sun and regular watering
origin: Native to Asia and widely cultivated worldwide for ornamental and cultural uses
description: A colorful flowering shrub used ornamentally and in herbal teas; many cultivars offer large showy flowers and are used culturally in garlands and traditional beverages.

name: Nithyapushpa
habitat: Warm, well-drained garden beds, open fields and well-lit roadside verges in tropical regions
origin: Native to Madagascar and widely naturalized and cultivated across tropical regions
description: A medicinal and ornamental flowering plant known for producing alkaloids used in cancer treatments; commonly grown for its bright, long-lasting flowers and traditional therapeutic uses.

name: Wood Sorrel
habitat: Open grasslands, gardens, lawns and disturbed soils where it tolerates a range of moisture conditions
origin: Cosmopolitan in distribution and now found worldwide across temperate and tropical regions
description: A small herb with trifoliate, sour-tasting leaves used in folk medicine and culinary garnishes; adaptable to varied habitats and often present as a common groundcover weed.

name: Tamarind
habitat: Tropical and subtropical climates, cultivated orchards, agroforestry systems and roadside plantings tolerant of seasonal drought
origin: Believed native to Africa, now widely grown across South Asia and tropical regions for its culinary pods
description: A long-lived tree producing tangy pods used extensively in cooking and condiments; fruit pulp is a staple in many regional cuisines and valued for culinary and medicinal applications.

name: Brahmi
habitat: Shallow freshwater wetlands, marshy edges and rice-field margins where water is shallow and soil is saturated
origin: Native to wetland regions of the Indian subcontinent and tropical Asia, commonly harvested from natural and cultivated stands
description: A creeping aquatic herb used extensively in Ayurvedic medicine to enhance memory, cognitive clarity and nervous system support; commonly prepared as extracts and tonics.

name: Sapota
habitat: Humid tropical lowlands, orchards and mixed home gardens with rich soils and consistent rainfall
origin: Native to Central America and now widely cultivated in tropical regions for its sweet fruits
description: A medium-sized fruit tree producing sweet brown fruits valued for fresh eating and processing; grown widely in backyard orchards and commercial plantations across the tropics.

name: Basale
habitat: Moist shaded gardens, trellised vegetable plots and humid tropical environments with rich soils
origin: Native to tropical Asia and widely cultivated in South and Southeast Asia as a leafy vegetable
description: A vigorous climbing leafy vegetable also known as Malabar spinach, used in soups and curries for its succulent leaves and heat tolerance compared to true spinach.

name: Avocado
habitat: Subtropical orchards, protected gardens and well-drained upland soils with moderate humidity and frost protection
origin: Native to Mexico and Central America and extensively cultivated worldwide in suitable subtropical regions
description: A nutrient-dense fruit tree producing creamy, oil-rich fruits highly valued for culinary uses, nutrition, and export markets; multiple horticultural types exist adapted to varied climates.

name: Ashwagandha
habitat: Dry, sandy soils of arid to semi-arid regions, open fields and home gardens with minimal irrigation
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and cultivated across South Asia for its traditional medicinal roots
description: An adaptogenic herb used in Ayurvedic medicine to alleviate stress and support vitality; roots and powders are commonly used in tonic formulations for overall well-being.

name: Nagadali
habitat: Forest edges, shaded scrub, and climbing through shrubs in warm, humid tropical forests
origin: Native to parts of India and Africa and cultivated for ornamental and medicinal uses
description: A striking climber with reflexed, colorful flowers used in traditional medicine and ornamental planting; tubers contain potent compounds and the plant is handled cautiously.

name: Arali
habitat: Tropical gardens and coastal plantings with well-drained soils and abundant sun exposure
origin: Native to Central America and widely cultivated in tropical regions for fragrant ornamental flowers
description: A small ornamental tree producing strongly fragrant blooms used in leis, perfumery and decorative plantings; prized for its long-lasting, showy flowers.

name: Ekka
habitat: Arid, disturbed wastelands and open scrub where it tolerates poor soils and drought
origin: Native to South Asia and widely distributed across dry tropical regions
description: A hardy shrub with milky latex used in traditional medicine and fiber production; contains bioactive compounds and is used cautiously in folk remedies.

name: Ganike
habitat: Sunny cultivated gardens, temple and ceremonial plantings, and annual borders with well-drained soils
origin: Native to Mexico and Central America and now widely cultivated for ornamental and ceremonial use
description: A tall marigold species commonly grown for bright, dense flower heads used in religious ceremonies, festivals and ornamental displays and sometimes for pest deterrence in gardens.

name: Tulasi
habitat: Home gardens, pots and temple courtyards with regular watering and bright light in warm climates
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and central to religious and medicinal cultivation across South Asia
description: A revered basil species with strong aromatic leaves used in daily worship and traditional remedies for respiratory and digestive health; commonly cultivated in households.

name: Honge
habitat: Coastal plains, riverbanks, and marginal lands tolerant of saline soils, often in mixed plantations
origin: Native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia and commonly planted for multipurpose uses
description: A multipurpose tree valued for seeds that yield oil suitable for biodiesel, timber, nitrogen-fixing properties and traditional medicinal uses in rural agroforestry systems.

name: Mint
habitat: Moist shaded garden beds, stream margins and cultivated herb plots with rich soils and regular watering
origin: Native to Europe and Asia with numerous species and hybrids widely cultivated worldwide
description: A versatile aromatic herb used in culinary, medicinal and aromatic applications; prized for its cooling flavor in teas, sauces, confectionery and traditional remedies for digestion.

name: Catharanthus
habitat: Sunny well-drained garden beds, roadsides and open fields in tropical climates
origin: Native to Madagascar and widely cultivated worldwide for ornamental and medicinal uses
description: A hardy flowering plant known for producing vinca alkaloids used in chemotherapy; also grown ornamentally for its profuse, colorful blooms and drought tolerance.

name: Papaya
habitat: Tropical and subtropical homesteads and plantations in fertile, well-drained soils with ample sunlight
origin: Native to Central America and widely naturalized throughout tropical regions for its fruits
description: A quick-growing fruit tree producing papain-rich fruits valued for digestion and culinary use; widely cultivated by smallholders and commercial growers in tropical countries.
